awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Advancing Robust Control and State Estimation of Converter-Based Power Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Future power grids, the nation’s most critical infrastructure, will be extremely difficult to manage due to large-scale integration of renewable energy resources. The strategy proposed in this project is aided by new grid technologies (converter-based assets in wind/solar farms and high-frequency sensing devices) that are developed and deployed to allow new real-time control-theoretic algorithms to be implemented with little overhead---while guaranteeing grid stability and resilience. The literature in this area had addressed various scientific research questions, but mostly adopted simplified models that cannot adequately capture the real-time operation of future grids. This project addresses this science gap by developing a new set of real-time algorithms, leading to a more robust operation of future power grids characterized with high penetration of renewable energy resources. These control algorithms can be implemented by grid operators throughout the nation. The project will also include: a) hosting an outreach workshop on renewable energy systems for a low-income, minority-majority, and female-only high school in San Antonio; b) organizing a technical industry workshop that showcases the created algorithms in the state of Iowa; c) disseminating the created scientific methods within the curricula at the University of Texas at San Antonio and Iowa State University.


This project aims at modernizing grid control methods which has traditionally relied on linear systems theory. In particular, the control-theoretic literature addressed a plethora of grid challenges with a focus on linearized, differential equation models whereby algebraic constraints (i.e., power flows) are eliminated. This is in contrast with the more realistic, complex nonlinear differential algebraic equation (NDAE) models. Linearizing grid models around operating points and eliminating algebraic constraints have proven to be a reliable strategy---a trade-off between complexity and tractability. Yet as grids are increasingly pushed to their limits via intermittent renewables, their physical states risk escaping operating regions due to a poor prediction of wind or solar. In lieu of linear differential equation models, control of NDAEs is highly beneficial for grids that are characterized by highly uncertain renewables. This guarantees grid stability for larger operating conditions. Given the limitations of present power system models and the lack of theoretical foundations for control and dynamic state estimation of grid NDAEs, this project will: 1) create a physically representative NDAE model of a power system with a mix of conventional machines and a variety of converter-based technologies; 2) investigate a general theory of dynamic state estimation and robust feedback control algorithms that consider the uncertain nature of power grids modeled via higher-order NDAEs; 3) obtain computationally tractable routines that can be implemented in control centers of power grids. The created theoretical foundations have applications in wide area control, converter-based control, centralized and decentralized and robust dynamic state estimation. This research is critical to guarantee acceptable performance of modern and future power systems and will lead to advancing the state-of-the-art of grid control studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Future power grids will be extremely difficult to manage: their spatiotemporal resolutions vary significantly, are inherently uncertain, and ought to be near carbon-free. Under these challenges, the real-time control of future grids is a major task for grid operators. The management of future grids still presents challenging theoretical questions for experts in this field. Various strategies exist to address the above challenges including: (a) legislation to impose carbon tariffs; (b) installing new transmission lines and building solar/wind farms; (c) allowing consumers to play a proactive role through demand response and time-sensitive energy reduction; (d) creating new computational methods that hedge risks through plug-and-play algorithms. Among all strategies, strategy (d) is an attractive alternative to other investment-heavy ones.

 

The literature in this area had addressed various scientific research questions, but mostly adopted simplified, linear models that cannot adequately capture the real-time operation of future grids with mostly renewables. In particular, this project aims at modernizing grid control methods which have traditionally relied on linear systems theory. Specifically, the control-theoretic literature addressed a plethora of grid challenges with a focus on linearized, differential equation models whereby algebraic constraints (i.e., power flows) are eliminated. This is in contrast with the more realistic, complex nonlinear differential algebraic equation (NDAE) models. Linearizing grid models around operating points and eliminating algebraic constraints have proven to be a reliable strategy---a trade-off between complexity and tractability. Yet as grids are increasingly pushed to their limits via intermittent renewables, their physical states risk escaping operating regions due to a poor prediction of wind or solar, a fault in transmission lines, or severe weather conditions.

 

In lieu of linear differential equation models, algorithms based on NDAEs are highly beneficial for grids that are characterized by highly uncertain renewables. This guarantees grid stability for larger operating conditions and hence establishes more robust methods for grid stability and control. Given the limitations of present power system models and the lack of theoretical foundations for control, monitoring, and dynamic state estimation of grid NDAEs, this project addresses this science gap by developing a new set of real-time algorithms, leading to a more robust operation of future power grids characterized with high penetration of renewables.

 

This project, in short, produces the first thorough effort in the literature to model, analyze, monitor, and control power grid transients (of advanced NDAE grid models) with performance guarantees. The project outcomes are as follows: (i) advanced models for solar- and wind-integrated power systems that accurately predict the evolution of power grid states; (ii) classification and parameterization of the nonlinear dynamics in power systems leading to simplified yet accurate grid models; (iii) robust monitoring, state estimation, and feedback control methods that utilize DAE system theory to improve power grid stability; (iv) stability and uncertainty propagation analyses in power grid dynamics that inform grid operators of how uncertainty from renewables propagates in advanced grid models; (v) model order reduction and system identification algorithms that simplify representation of complex power network physics based on input-output data without resorting to a detailed, physics-based model; (vi) a host of open source algorithms, numerical simulations, and case studies that demonstrate the applicability of the outcomes (i)--(v) to realistic power system templates, including small-scale power networks to networks with thousands of buses and transmission lines. The project produced a large body of literature, published in the field’s most competitive journals and conference proceedings, that advanced the state-of-the-art and has the potential to improve future power grids.
